processed_hadiths.english_translation: Abu Ismail settled in Medina. He heard from Bashir ibn Muhajar, and Hisham ibn Ishaq, and Ja'far ibn Muhammad. Abu Thabit said: Muhammad ibn Ubaydillah died on the night of Friday, seven nights having passed of Jumada al-Awwal in the year 187 AH. Abd al-Rahman ibn Mahdi narrated from him.

processed_hadiths.english_translation: Ibn Uyaynah said: He held the opinion of the Ibadi. Muhammad said: Narrated to us Ibn Mahdi, heard al-Aswad ibn Shayban, from Hajib, from Jabir ibn Zayd, from Ibn Abbas, he said: The innovation in religion is of two kinds - the most severe of which is the innovation of the tongue, and it was not corroborated.

narrators.name: Hajib
narrators.alternative_names: Unknown - possibly the Hajib mentioned in this work

narrators.name: Ibn Abbas
narrators.full_name: Abdullah ibn Abbas ibn Abd al-Muttalib ibn Hashim

chainIssues: Unidentified narrator 'Muhammad' acts as a compiler or intermediary

potential_issues.issue: Unidentified narrator Muhammad breaks the chain of transmission
potential_issues.impact: An unknown narrator acting as an intermediary and compiler significantly weakens the chain. This breaks the direct transmission from Ibn Mahdi onward.

potential_issues.issue: Identity of Hajib is ambiguous
potential_issues.impact: The Hajib in this chain could be any of the numerous Hajibs mentioned in this biographical work. Without clear identification, verification of the narration is impossible.

potential_issues.issue: Multiple instances of indirect 'an (عَنْ) in chain
potential_issues.impact: The chain contains several 'an terms which could indicate indirect transmission. Combined with the other weaknesses, this affects reliability.

potential_issues.issue: Scholarly note: 'It was not corroborated' (ولم يتابع فِيهِ)
potential_issues.impact: This phrase indicates that scholars of hadith found no supporting corroboration for this narration. This is a critical note about the hadith's weakness.

processed_hadiths.english_translation: The father of Muhammad al-Basri heard from al-Hasan. Umm Hafs is the mother of one of the children of Imran ibn Husain. Waki' said: His kunya is Abu Muhammad. Mu'attar said: He is al-Jariri. Al-Hasan ibn al-Sabah from al-'Akli said: His kunya is Abu al-Hikam.

chainIssues: Multiple conflicting accounts of identity and kunya (agnomen)
Father of Muhammad al-Basri is unnamed and unidentified
The entry provides three different kunya attributions (Abu Muhammad, al-Jariri, Abu al-Hikam)
Mu'attar and al-Hasan ibn al-Sabah are not clearly identified
This appears to be a compilation of scholarly disagreement rather than a hadith

potential_issues.issue: Multiple conflicting kunya attributions from different sources
potential_issues.impact: Waki' attributes one kunya (Abu Muhammad), Mu'attar suggests identity as al-Jariri, and al-Hasan ibn al-Sabah provides yet another (Abu al-Hikam). This indicates significant scholarly disagreement.

potential_issues.issue: Mu'attar and al-Hasan ibn al-Sabah are both majhul al-hal
potential_issues.impact: These commentators who provide alternative accounts are not clearly identified, undermining the reliability of their attributions.

potential_issues.issue: No hadith matn provided

processed_hadiths.english_translation: From Ibn Mas'ud: He curtailed one of the two greetings. Biyan said this, from Yazid, we narrated to us Hammam, from Qatadah, from al-Radra'.

chainIssues: Biyan is not clearly identified (majhul al-hal)
Yazid is not clearly identified (majhul al-hal)
Al-Radra' is not clearly identified (majhul al-hal)
Multiple indirect transmission terms ('an) in chain
Qatadah is known for concealment (mudallis type 3)
The hadith text mentions 'curtailing one of the two greetings' but lacks context

potential_issues.issue: Multiple unidentified or majhul al-hal narrators in the chain
potential_issues.impact: Biyan, Yazid, and al-Radra' are not clearly identified, significantly weakening the chain. Without knowing who these people are, we cannot assess their reliability.

potential_issues.issue: Qatadah is a mudallis (concealer of sources, category 3)
potential_issues.impact: Qatadah's use of 'an (عَنْ) requires direct transmission verification. His 'an term here creates ambiguity about direct hearing from al-Radra'.

potential_issues.issue: Multiple indirect transmission terms in the chain
potential_issues.impact: The chain contains several 'an terms which could indicate indirect transmission, especially problematic with the unknown narrators.

potential_issues.issue: The hadith text itself is unclear about context
potential_issues.impact: The reference to 'curtailing one of the two greetings' (التسليمتين - two greetings/salutations in prayer) lacks context about what this action refers to and why it is mentioned.

processed_hadiths.IISGrade: Questionable But Might Be Acceptable
Topics: Incident of curtailing or abbreviating prayer greetings
Discussion of the two greetings in Islamic prayer practice
Description of action related to prayer salutations
